intro: Salix barclayi var. conjuncta, commonly known as the Sierra Nevada willow, is a shrub or small tree native to the western United States. It is characterized by its narrow, willow-like leaves and catkin-like flowers, which are typical of the Salicaceae family. The plant thrives in moist, well-drained soils along streambanks and in riparian habitats. Its growth form and flowering patterns make it an important component of its ecosystem. It is often used in ecological restoration projects due to its ability to stabilize riverbanks and provide habitat for wildlife.
